In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: An't please your lordship, I hear his Majesty is return'd with some discomfort from Wales.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I hear, moreover, his Highness is fall'n into this same whoreson apoplexy.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well God mend him! I pray you let me speak with you.

Your lordship may minister the potion of imprisonment to me in respect of poverty; but how I should be your patient to follow your prescriptions, the wise may make some dram of a scruple, or indeed a scruple itself.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Not so, my lord. Your ill angel is light; but  hope he that looks upon me will take me without weighing. And yet in some respects, I grant, I cannot go- I cannot tell. Virtue is of so little regard in these costermongers' times that true valour is turn'd berod; pregnancy is made a tapster, and his quick wit wasted in giving reckonings; all the other gifts appertinent to man, as the malice of this age shapes them, are not worth a gooseberry. You that are old consider not the capacities of us that are young; you do measure the heat of our livers with the bitterness of your galls; and we that are in the vaward of our youth, must confess, are wags too.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Do you set down your name in the scroll of youth, that are written down old with all the characters of age? Have you not a moist eye, a dry hand, a yellow cheek, a white beard, a decreasing leg, an increasing belly? Is not your voice broken, your wind short, your chin double, your wit single, and every part about you blasted with antiquity? And will you yet call yourself young? Fie, fie, fie, Sir John!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, I was born about three of the clock in the afternoon, with a white head and something a round belly. For my voice- I have lost it with hallooing and singing of anthems. To approve my youth further, I will not. The truth is, I am only old in judgment and understanding; and he that will caper with me for a thousand marks, let him lend me the money, and have at him. For the box of the ear that the Prince gave you- he gave it like a rude prince, and you took it like a sensible lord. I have check'd him for it; and the young lion repents- marry, not in ashes and sackcloth, but in new silk and old sack.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea; I thank your pretty sweet wit for it. But look you pray, all you that kiss my Lady Peace at home, that our armies join not in a hot day; for, by the Lord, I take but two shirts out with me, and I mean not to sweat extraordinarily. If it be a hot day, and I brandish anything but a bottle, I would I might never spit white again. There is not a dangerous action can peep out his head but I am thrust upon it. Well, I cannot last ever; but it was alway yet the trick of our English nation, if they have a good thing, to make it too common. If ye will needs say I am an old man, you should give me rest. I would to God my name were not so terrible to the enemy as it is. I were better to be eaten to death with a rust than to be scoured to nothing with perpetual motion.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sir John, Sir John, I am well acquainted with your manner of wrenching the true cause the false way. It is not a confident brow, nor the throng of words that come with such more than impudent sauciness from you, can thrust me from a level consideration. You have, as it appears to me, practis'd upon the easy yielding spirit of this woman, and made her serve your uses both in purse and in person.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, in truth, my lord.

I say to you I do desire deliverance from these officers, being upon hasty employment in the King's affairs.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You speak as having power to do wrong; but answer in th' effect of your reputation, and satisfy the poor woman.

Let it be ten pound, if thou canst. Come, and 'twere not for thy humours, there's not a better wench in England. Go, wash thy face, and draw the action. Come, thou must not be in this humour with me; dost not know me? Come, come, I know thou wast set on to this.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, a prince should not be so loosely studied as to remember so weak a composition.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Belike then my appetite was not-princely got; for, by my troth, I do now remember the poor creature, small beer. But indeed these humble considerations make me out of love with my greatness. What a disgrace is it to me to remember thy name, or to know thy face to-morrow, or to take note how many pair of silk stockings thou hast- viz., these, and those that were thy peach-colour'd ones- or to bear the inventory of thy shirts- as, one for superfluity, and another for use! But that the tennis-court-keeper knows better than I; for it is a low ebb of linen with thee when thou keepest not racket there; as thou hast not done a great while, because the rest of thy low countries have made a shift to eat up thy holland. And God knows whether those that bawl out of the ruins of thy linen shall inherit his kingdom; but the midwives say the children are not in the fault; whereupon the world increases, and kindreds are mightily strengthened.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV

You are the weaker vessel, as as they say, the emptier vessel.

Shut the door. There comes no swaggerers here; I have not liv'd all this while to have swaggering now. Shut the door, I pray you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Dost thou hear, hostess?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: She is pistol-proof, sir; you shall not hardly offend her.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I know you, Mistress Dorothy.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Captain! Thou abominable damn'd cheater, art thou not ashamed to be called captain? An captains were of my mind, they would truncheon you out, for taking their names upon you before you have earn'd them. You a captain! you slave, for what? For tearing a poor whore's ruff in a bawdy-house? He a captain! hang him, rogue! He lives upon mouldy stew'd prunes and dried cakes. A captain! God's light, these villains will make the word as odious as the word 'occupy'; which was an excellent good word before it was ill sorted. Therefore captains had need look to't.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Hark thee hither, Mistress Doll.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Not I! I tell thee what, Corporal Bardolph, I could tear her; I'll be reveng'd of her.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Pray thee go down.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good Captain Peesel, be quiet; 'tis very late, i' faith; I beseek you now, aggravate your choler.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By my troth, Captain, these are very bitter words.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Be gone, good ancient; this will grow to a brawl anon.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Die men like dogs! Give crowns like pins! Have we not Hiren here?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O' my word, Captain, there's none such here. What the good-year! do you think I would deny her? For God's sake, be quiet.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Pistol, I would be quiet.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sweet knight, I kiss thy neaf. What! we have seen the seven stars.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: For God's sake thrust him down stairs; I cannot endure such a fustian rascal.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thrust him down stairs! Know we not Galloway nags?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, get you down stairs.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here's goodly stuff toward!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Give me my rapier, boy.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I pray thee, Jack, I pray thee, do not draw.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I pray thee, Jack, be quiet; the rascal's gone. Ah, you whoreson little valiant villain, you!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Have you turn'd him out a doors?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, sir. The rascal's drunk. You have hurt him, sir, i' th' shoulder.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A rascal! to brave me!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A rascally slave! I will toss the rogue in a blanket.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The music is come, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let them play. Play, sirs. Sit on my knee, Don. A rascal bragging slave! The rogue fled from me like quick-silver.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Peace, good Doll! Do not speak like a death's-head; do not bid me remember mine end.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sirrah, what humour's the Prince of?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A good shallow young fellow. 'A would have made a good pantler; 'a would ha' chipp'd bread well.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: They say Poins has a good wit.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why does the Prince love him so, then?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Because their legs are both of a bigness, and 'a plays at quoits well, and eats conger and fennel, and drinks off candles' ends for flap-dragons, and rides the wild mare with the boys, and jumps upon join'd-stools, and swears with a good grace, and wears his boots very smooth, like unto the sign of the Leg, and breeds no bate with telling of discreet stories; and such other gambol faculties 'a has, that show a weak mind and an able body, for the which the Prince admits him. For the Prince himself is such another; the weight of a hair will turn the scales between their avoirdupois.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Would not this nave of a wheel have his ears cut off?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let's beat him before his whore.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Look whe'er the wither'd elder hath not his poll claw'd like a parrot.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is it not strange that desire should so many years outlive performance?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Kiss me, Doll.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Saturn and Venus this year in conjunction! What says th' almanac to that?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And look whether the fiery Trigon, his man, be not lisping to his master's old tables, his note-book, his counsel-keeper.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thou dost give me flattering busses.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By my troth, I kiss thee with a most constant heart.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am old, I am old.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I love thee better than I love e'er a scurvy young boy of them all.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Some sack, Francis.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Anon, anon, sir.                   [Advancing]

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ha! a bastard son of the King's? And art thou not Poins his brother?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, thou globe of sinful continents, what a life dost thou lead!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A better than thou. I am a gentleman: thou art a drawer.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Very true, sir, and I come to draw you out by the ears.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How, you fat fool! I scorn you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, he will drive you out of your revenge and turn all to a merriment, if you take not the heat.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: YOU whoreson candle-mine, you, how vilely did you speak of me even now before this honest, virtuous, civil gentlewoman!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: God's blessing of your good heart! and so she is, by my troth.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Didst thou hear me?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, no, no; not so; I did not think thou wast within hearing.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I shall drive you then to confess the wilful abuse, and then I know how to handle you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No abuse, Hal, o' mine honour; no abuse.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Not- to dispraise me, and call me pander, and bread-chipper, and I know not what!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No abuse, Hal.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No abuse!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No abuse, Ned, i' th' world; honest Ned, none. I disprais'd him before the wicked- that the wicked might not fall in love with thee; in which doing, I have done the part of a careful friend and a true subject; and thy father is to give me thanks for it. No abuse, Hal; none, Ned, none; no, faith, boys, none.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: See now, whether pure fear and entire cowardice doth not make thee wrong this virtuous gentlewoman to close with us? Is she of the wicked? Is thine hostess here of the wicked? Or is thy boy of the wicked? Or honest Bardolph, whose zeal burns in his nose, of the wicked?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Answer, thou dead elm, answer.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The fiend hath prick'd down Bardolph irrecoverable; and his face is Lucifer's privy-kitchen, where he doth nothing but roast malt-worms. For the boy- there is a good angel about him; but the devil outbids him too.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: For the women?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: For one of them- she's in hell already, and burns poor souls. For th' other- I owe her money; and whether she be damn'd for that, I know not.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, I warrant you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: All vict'lers do so. What's a joint of mutton or two in a whole Lent?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You, gentlewoman-

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What says your Grace?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Peto, how now! What news?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [To the PAGE]. Pay the musicians, sirrah.- Farewell, hostess; farewell, Doll. You see, my good wenches, how men of merit are sought after; the undeserver may sleep, when the man of action is call'd on. Farewell, good wenches. If I be not sent away post, I will see you again ere I go.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [ Within]  Mistress Tearsheet!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What's the matter?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [ Within]  Bid Mistress Tearsheet come to my master.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Many good morrows to your Majesty!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is it good morrow, lords?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis one o'clock, and past.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We have, my liege.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come on, come on, come on; give me your hand, sir; give me your hand, sir. An early stirrer, by the rood! And how doth my good cousin Silence?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good morrow, good cousin Shallow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And how doth my cousin, your bed-fellow? and your fairest daughter and mine, my god-daughter Ellen?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Alas, a black ousel, cousin Shallow!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By yea and no, sir. I dare say my cousin William is become a good scholar; he is at Oxford still, is he not?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Indeed, sir, to my cost.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You were call'd 'lusty Shallow' then, cousin.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: This Sir John, cousin, that comes hither anon about soldiers?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We shall all follow, cousin.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By my troth, I was not there.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Death is certain. Is old Double of your town living yet?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Dead, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thereafter as they be- a score of good ewes may be worth ten pounds.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here come two of Sir John Falstaffs men, as I think.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good morrow, honest gentlemen.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I beseech you, which is Justice Shallow?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am Robert Shallow, sir, a poor esquire of this county, and one of the King's justices of the peace. What is your good pleasure with me?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sir, pardon; a soldier is better accommodated than with a wife.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good Master Silence, it well befits you should be of the peace.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your good worship is welcome.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Fie! this is hot weather. Gentlemen, have you provided me here half a dozen sufficient men?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Marry, have we, sir. Will you sit?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let me see them, I beseech you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Where's the roll? Where's the roll? Where's the roll? Let me see, let me see, let me see. So, so, so, so,- so, so- yea, marry, sir. Rafe Mouldy! Let them appear as I call; let them do so, let them do so. Let me see; where is Mouldy?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here, an't please you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What think you, Sir John? A good-limb'd fellow; young, strong, and of good friends.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is thy name Mouldy?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, an't please you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis the more time thou wert us'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Prick him.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I was prick'd well enough before, an you could have let me alone. My old dame will be undone now for one to do her husbandry and her drudgery. You need not to have prick'd me; there are other men fitter to go out than I.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go to; peace, Mouldy; you shall go. Mouldy, it is time you were spent.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Spent!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, marry, let me have him to sit under. He's like to be a cold soldier.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Where's Shadow?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Shadow, whose son art thou?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My mother's son, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Do you like him, Sir John?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Shadow will serve for summer. Prick him; for we have a number of shadows fill up the muster-book.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thomas Wart!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Where's he?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is thy name Wart?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thou art a very ragged wart.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Shall I prick him, Sir John?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It were superfluous; for his apparel is built upon his back, and the whole frame stands upon pins. Prick him no more.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ha, ha, ha! You can do it, sir; you can do it. I commend you well. Francis Feeble!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What trade art thou, Feeble?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A woman's tailor, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Shall I prick him, sir?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You may; but if he had been a man's tailor, he'd ha' prick'd you. Wilt thou make as many holes in an enemy's battle as thou hast done in a woman's petticoat?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I will do my good will, sir; you can have no more.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I would Wart might have gone, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I would thou wert a man's tailor, that thou mightst mend him and make him fit to go. I cannot put him to a private soldier, that is the leader of so many thousands. Let that suffice, most forcible Feeble.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It shall suffice, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am bound to thee, reverend Feeble. Who is next?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Peter Bullcalf o' th' green!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, marry, let's see Bullcalf.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Fore God, a likely fellow! Come, prick me Bullcalf till he roar again.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O Lord! good my lord captain-

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, dost thou roar before thou art prick'd?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O Lord, sir! I am a diseased man.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What disease hast thou?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A whoreson cold, sir, a cough, sir, which I caught with ringing in the King's affairs upon his coronation day, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, thou shalt go to the wars in a gown. We will have away thy cold; and I will take such order that thy friends shall ring for thee. Is here all?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here is two more call'd than your number. You must have but four here, sir; and so, I pray you, go in with me to dinner.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, I will go drink with you, but I cannot tarry dinner. I am glad to see you, by my troth, Master Shallow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, Sir John, do you remember since we lay all night in the windmill in Saint George's Field?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No more of that, Master Shallow, no more of that.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ha, 'twas a merry night. And is Jane Nightwork alive?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: She lives, Master Shallow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: She never could away with me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By the mass, I could anger her to th' heart. She was then a bona-roba. Doth she hold her own well?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Old, old, Master Shallow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, she must be old; she cannot choose but be old; certain she's old; and had Robin Nightwork, by old Nightwork, before I came to Clement's Inn.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: That's fifty-five year ago.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ha, cousin Silence, that thou hadst seen that that this knight and I have seen! Ha, Sir John, said I well?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We have heard the chimes at midnight, Master Shallow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good Master Corporate Bardolph, stand my friend; and here's four Harry ten shillings in French crowns for you. In very truth, sir, I had as lief be hang'd, sir, as go. And yet, for mine own part, sir, I do not care; but rather because I am unwilling and, for mine own part, have a desire to stay with my friends; else, sir, I did not care for mine own part so much.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go to; stand aside.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And, good Master Corporal Captain, for my old dame's sake, stand my friend. She has nobody to do anything about her when I am gone; and she is old, and cannot help herself. You shall have forty, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go to; stand aside.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By my troth, I care not; a man can die but once; we owe God a death. I'll ne'er bear a base mind. An't be my destiny, so; an't be not, so. No man's too good to serve 's Prince; and, let it go which way it will, he that dies this year is quit for the next.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well said; th'art a good fellow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, sir, which men shall I have?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Four of which you please.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sir, a word with you. I have three pound to free Mouldy and Bullcalf.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go to; well.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, Sir John, which four will you have?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Do you choose for me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Marry, then- Mouldy, Bullcalf, Feeble, and Shadow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Mouldy and Bullcalf: for you, Mouldy, stay at home till you are past service; and for your part, Bullcalf, grow you come unto it. I will none of you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sir John, Sir John, do not yourself wrong. They are your likeliest men, and I would have you serv'd with the best.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Hold, Wart. Traverse- thus, thus, thus.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Fore God, would you would.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go to; I have spoke at a word. God keep you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What is this forest call'd

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis Gaultree Forest, an't shall please your Grace.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We have sent forth already.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now, what news?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What well-appointed leader fronts us here?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I think it is my Lord of Westmoreland.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well, by my will we shall admit no parley.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, we will do so.          Exit WESTMORELAND

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your Grace of York, in God's name then, set forward.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I take your princely word for these redresses.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To you, my noble Lord of Westmoreland.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I do not doubt you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Believe me, I am passing light in spirit.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The word of peace is rend'red. Hark, how they shout!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: This had been cheerful after victory.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is this proceeding just and honourable?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is your assembly so?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Will you thus break your faith?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What's your name, sir? Of what condition are you, and of what place, I pray?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am a knight sir; and my name is Colville of the Dale.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well then, Colville is your name, a knight is your degree, and your place the Dale. Colville shall still be your name, a traitor your degree, and the dungeon your place- a place deep enough; so shall you be still Colville of the Dale.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Are not you Sir John Falstaff?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: As good a man as he, sir, whoe'er I am. Do you yield, sir, or shall I sweat for you? If I do sweat, they are the drops of thy lovers, and they weep for thy death; therefore rouse up fear and trembling, and do observance to my mercy.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I think you are Sir John Falstaff, and in that thought yield me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It was more of his courtesy than your deserving.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I know not. Here he is, and here I yield him; and I beseech your Grace, let it be book'd with the rest of this day's deeds; or, by the Lord, I will have it in a particular ballad else, with mine own picture on the top on't, Colville kissing my foot; to the which course if I be enforc'd, if you do not all show like gilt twopences to me, and I, in the clear sky of fame, o'ershine you as much as the full moon doth the cinders of the element, which show like pins' heads to her, believe not the word of the noble. Therefore let me have right, and let desert mount.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thine's too heavy to mount.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let it shine, then.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thine's too thick to shine.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let it do something, my good lord, that may do me good, and call it what you will.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is thy name Colville?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It is, my lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A famous rebel art thou, Colville.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And a famous true subject took him.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now, have you left pursuit?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Retreat is made, and execution stay'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The army is discharged all and gone.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I think he's gone to hunt, my lord, at Windsor.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And how accompanied?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I do not know, my lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is not his brother, Thomas of Clarence, with him?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, my good lord, he is in presence here.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What would my lord and father?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I shall observe him with all care and love.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why art thou not at Windsor with him, Thomas?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: He is not there to-day; he dines in London.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And how accompanied? Canst thou tell that?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: With Poins, and other his continual followers.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Comfort, your Majesty!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O my royal father!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My sovereign lord, cheer up yourself, look up.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Speak lower, Princes, for the King recovers.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: This apoplexy will certain be his end.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Call for the music in the other room.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Set me the crown upon my pillow here.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: His eye is hollow, and he changes much.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Who saw the Duke of Clarence?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am here, brother, full of heaviness.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Exceeding ill.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Heard he the good news yet? Tell it him.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: He alt'red much upon the hearing it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: If he be sick with joy, he'll recover without physic.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let us withdraw into the other room.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Will't please your Grace to go along with us?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Doth the King call?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What would your Majesty? How fares your Grace?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why did you leave me here alone, my lords?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: This door is open; he is gone this way.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: He came not through the chamber where we stay'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Where is the crown? Who took it from my pillow?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: When we withdrew, my liege, we left it here.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I never thought to hear you speak again.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Look, look, here comes my John of Lancaster.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Health, peace, and happiness, to my royal father!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My Lord of Warwick!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis call'd Jerusalem, my noble lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You must excuse me, Master Robert Shallow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Marry, sir, thus: those precepts cannot be served; and, again, sir- shall we sow the headland with wheat?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: With red wheat, Davy. But for William cook- are there no young pigeons?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yes, sir. Here is now the smith's note for shoeing and plough-irons.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let it be cast, and paid. Sir John, you shall not be excused.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now, sir, a new link to the bucket must needs be had; and, sir, do you mean to stop any of William's wages about the sack he lost the other day at Hinckley fair?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'A shall answer it. Some pigeons, Davy, a couple of short-legg'd hens, a joint of mutton, and any pretty little tiny kickshaws, tell William cook.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Doth the man of war stay all night, sir?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, Davy; I will use him well. A friend i' th' court is better than a penny in purse. Use his men well, Davy; for they are arrant knaves and will backbite.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No worse than they are backbitten, sir; for they have marvellous foul linen.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well conceited, Davy- about thy business, Davy.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I beseech you, sir, to countenance William Visor of Woncot against Clement Perkes o' th' hill.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I grant your worship that he is a knave, sir; but yet God forbid, sir, but a knave should have some countenance at his friend's request. An honest man, sir, is able to speak for himself, when a knave is not. I have serv'd your worship truly, sir, this eight years; an I cannot once or twice in a quarter bear out a knave against an honest man, I have but a very little credit with your worship. The knave is mine honest friend, sir; therefore, I beseech you, let him be countenanc'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go to; I say he shall have no wrong. Look about,

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Exit DAVY]  Where are you, Sir John? Come, come, come, off with your boots. Give me your hand, Master Bardolph.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am glad to see your worship.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Within]  Sir John!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How now, my Lord Chief Justice; whither away?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How doth the King?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Exceeding well; his cares are now all ended.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I hope, not dead.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Indeed, I think the young king loves you not.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O God, I fear all will be overturn'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good morrow, cousin Warwick, good morrow.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good morrow, cousin.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We meet like men that had forgot to speak.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well, peace be with him that hath made us heavy!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Peace be with us, lest we be heavier!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good morrow, and God save your Majesty!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We hope no otherwise from your Majesty.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, you shall see my orchard, where, in an arbour, we will eat a last year's pippin of mine own graffing, with a dish of caraways, and so forth. Come, cousin Silence. And then to bed.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Fore God, you have here a goodly dwelling and rich.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: This Davy serves you for good uses; he is your serving-man and your husband.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: There's a merry heart! Good Master Silence, I'll give you a health for that anon.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Give Master Bardolph some wine, Davy.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Be merry, Master Bardolph; and, my little soldier there, be merry.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I did not think Master Silence had been a man of this mettle.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [To BARDOLPH]  There's a dish of leather-coats for you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Davy!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well said, Master Silence.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: An we shall be merry, now comes in the sweet o' th' night.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Health and long life to you, Master Silence!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Honest Bardolph, welcome; if thou want'st anything and wilt not call, beshrew thy heart. Welcome, my little tiny thief and welcome indeed too. I'll drink to Master Bardolph, and to all the cabileros about London.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I hope to see London once ere I die.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: An I might see you there, Davy!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By the mass, you'R crack a quart together- ha! will you not, Master Bardolph?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, sir, in a pottle-pot.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By God's liggens, I thank thee. The knave will stick by thee, I can assure thee that. 'A will not out, 'a; 'tis true bred.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I'll stick by him, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [To SILENCE, who has drunk a bumper]  Why, now you have done me right.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis so.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IV

For though I speak it to you, I think the King is but a man as I am: the violet smells to him as it doth to me; the element shows to him as it doth to me; all his senses have but human conditions; his ceremonies laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man; and though his affections are higher mounted than ours, yet, when they stoop, they stoop with the like wing. Therefore, when he sees reason of fears, as we do, his fears, out of doubt, be of the same relish as ours are; yet, in reason, no man should possess him with any appearance of fear, lest he, by showing it, should dishearten his army.

I am afeard there are few die well that die in a battle; for how can they charitably dispose of anything when blood is their argument? Now, if these men do not die well, it will be a black matter for the King that led them to it; who to disobey were against all proportion of subjection.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My liege, this was my glove: here is the fellow of it; and he that I gave it to in change promis'd to wear it in his cap; I promis'd to strike him if he did; I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I have been as good as my word.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your Majesty hear now, saving your Majesty's manhood, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly, lousy knave it is; I hope your Majesty is pear me testimony and witness, and will avouchment, that this is the glove of Alencon that your Majesty is give me; in your conscience, now.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: An please your Majesty, let his neck answer for it, if there is any martial law in the world.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How canst thou make me satisfaction?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: All offences, my lord, come from the heart; never came any from mine that might offend your Majesty.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It was ourself thou didst abuse.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your Majesty came not like yourself: you appear'd to me but as a common man; witness the night, your garments, your lowliness; and what your Highness suffer'd under that shape I beseech you take it for your own fault, and not mine; for had you been as I took you for, I made no offence; therefore, I beseech your Highness pardon me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By this day and this light, the fellow has mettle enough in his belly: hold, there is twelve pence for you; and I pray you to serve God, and keep you out of prawls, and prabbles, and quarrels, and dissensions, and, I warrant you, it is the better for you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I will none of your money.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now, herald, are the dead numb'red?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What prisoners of good sort are taken, uncle?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis wonderful!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is it not lawful, an please your Majesty, to tell how many is kill'd?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yes, my conscience, he did us great good.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, here he comes, swelling like a turkey-cock.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I peseech you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave, at my desires, and my requests, and my petitions, to eat, look you, this leek; because, look you, you do not love it, nor your affections, and your appetites, and your digestions, does not agree with it, I would desire you to eat it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Not for Cadwallader and all his goats.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: There is one goat for you.  [Strikes him]  Will you be so good, scald knave, as eat it?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Base Troyan, thou shalt die.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You say very true, scald knave- when God's will is. I will desire you to live in the meantime, and eat your victuals; come, there is sauce for it.  [Striking him again]  You call'd me yesterday mountain-squire; but I will make you to-day a squire of low degree. I pray you fall to; if you can mock a leek, you can eat a leek.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Enough, Captain, you have astonish'd him.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I say I will make him eat some part of my leek, or I will peat his pate four days. Bite, I pray you, it is good for your green wound and your ploody coxcomb.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Must I bite?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yes, certainly, and out of doubt, and out of question too, and ambiguides.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Eat, I pray you; will you have some more sauce to your leek? There is not enough leek to swear by.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Quiet thy cudgel: thou dost see I eat.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, leeks is good. Hold you, there is a groat to heal your pate.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Me a groat!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yes, verily and in truth, you shall take it; or I have another leek in my pocket which you shall eat.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I take thy groat in earnest of revenge.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: If I owe you anything I will pay you in cudgels; you shall be a woodmonger, and buy nothing of me but cudgels. God bye you, and keep you, and heal your pate.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: All hell shall stir for this.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go, go: you are a couterfeit cowardly knave. Will you mock at an ancient tradition, begun upon an honourable respect, and worn as a memorable trophy of predeceased valour, and dare not avouch in your deeds any of your words? I have seen you gleeking and galling at this gentleman twice or thrice. You thought, because he could not speak English in the native garb, he could not therefore handle an English cudgel; you find it otherwise, and henceforth let a Welsh correction teach you a good English condition. Fare ye well.                                Exit

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To cry amen to that, thus we appear.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You English princes an, I do salute you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your Majesty shall mock me; I cannot speak your England.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell vat is like me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Que dit-il? que je suis semblable a les anges?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Oui, vraiment, sauf votre grace, ainsi dit-il.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I said so, dear Katherine, and I must not blush to affirm it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O bon Dieu! les langues des hommes sont pleines de tromperies.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What says she, fair one? that the tongues of men are full of deceits?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits- dat is de Princess.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sauf votre honneur, me understand well.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is it possible dat I sould love de enemy of France?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I cannot tell vat is dat.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sauf votre honneur, le Francais que vous parlez, il est meilleur que l'Anglais lequel je parle.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I cannot tell.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I do not know dat.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your Majestee ave fausse French enough to deceive de most sage damoiselle dat is en France.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Dat is as it shall please de roi mon pere.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, it will please him well, Kate- it shall please him, Kate.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Den it sall also content me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Upon that I kiss your hand, and I can you my queen.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Laissez, mon seigneur, laissez, laissez! Ma foi, je ne veux point que vous abaissiez votre grandeur en baisant la main d'une, notre seigneur, indigne serviteur; excusez-moi, je vous supplie, mon tres puissant seigneur.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Then I will kiss your lips, Kate.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Les dames et demoiselles pour etre baisees devant leur noces, il n'est pas la coutume de France.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Madame my interpreter, what says she?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Dat it is not be de fashion pour le ladies of France- I cannot tell vat is baiser en Anglish.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To kiss.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your Majestee entendre bettre que moi.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kiss before they are married, would she say?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Oui, vraiment.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I would have her learn, my fair cousin, how perfectly I love her; and that is good English.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is she not apt?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition is not smooth; so that, having neither the voice nor the heart of flattery about me, I cannot so conjure up the spirit of love in her that he will appear in his true likeness.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Pardon the frankness of my mirth, if I answer you for that. If you would conjure in her, you must make a circle; if conjure up love in her in his true likeness, he must appear naked and blind. Can you blame her, then, being a maid yet ros'd over with the virgin crimson of modesty, if she deny the appearance of a naked blind boy in her naked seeing self? It were, my lord, a hard condition for a maid to consign to.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yet they do wink and yield, as love is blind and enforces.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: They are then excus'd, my lord, when they see not what they do.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Then, good my lord, teach your cousin to consent winking.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I will wink on her to consent, my lord, if you will teach her to know my meaning; for maids well summer'd and warm kept are like flies at Bartholomew-tide, blind, though they have their eyes; and then they will endure handling, which before would not abide looking on.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: This moral ties me over to time and a hot summer; and so I shall catch the fly, your cousin, in the latter end, and she must be blind too.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: As love is, my lord, before it loves.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yes, my lord, you see them perspectively, the cities turned into a maid; for they are all girdled with maiden walls that war hath never ent'red.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Shall Kate be my wife?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: So please you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am content, so the maiden cities you talk of may wait on her; so the maid that stood in the way for my wish shall show me the way to my will.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We have consented to all terms of reason.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is't so, my lords of England?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Amen!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF KING HENRY THE FIFTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Amen!

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How were they lost? What treachery was us'd?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Bastard of Orleans, thrice welcome to us.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Christ's Mother helps me, else I were too weak.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What she says I'll confirm; we'll fight it out.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How now, ambitious Humphry! What means this?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Mayor, farewell; thou dost but what thou mayst.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yet tell'st thou not how thou wert entertain'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O Lord, have mercy on me, woeful man!

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A maid, they say.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ascend, brave Talbot; we will follow thee.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Agreed; I'll to yond corner.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I to this.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How now, my lords? What, all unready so?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Mine was secure.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Madam, I will.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Prisoner! To whom?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Laughest thou, wretch? Thy mirth shall turn to moan.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, art not thou the man?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am indeed.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Then have I substance too.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well, well, come on; who else?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now, Somerset, where is your argument?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE FIRST PART OF HENRY THE SIXTH
