In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We'll all assist you; he that flies shall die.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Arm'd as we are, let's stay within this house.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: If I be not, heavens be reveng'd on me!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The hope thereof makes Clifford mourn in steel.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Be patient, gentle Earl of Westmoreland.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well hast thou spoken, cousin; be it so.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But when the Duke is slain they'll quickly fly.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am thine.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: For shame, come down; he made thee Duke of York.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thy father was a traitor to the crown.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Whom should he follow but his natural king?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: True, Clifford; and that's Richard Duke of York.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And shall I stand, and thou sit in my throne?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It must and shall be so; content thyself.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be King.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Poor Clifford, how I scorn his worthless threats!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sweet father, do so; set it on your head.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sound drums and trumpets, and the King will fly.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Sons, peace!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Peace thou! and give King Henry leave to speak.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be King.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Twas by rebellion against his king.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What then?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My conscience tells me he is lawful King.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside] All will revolt from me, and turn to him.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Depos'd he shall be, in despite of all.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What wrong is this unto the Prince your son!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What good is this to England and himself!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Base, fearful, and despairing Henry!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How hast thou injur'd both thyself and or us!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I cannot stay to hear these articles.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nor I.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, cousin, let us tell the Queen these news.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: They seek revenge, and therefore will not yield.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ah, Exeter!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why should you sigh, my lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Long live King Henry! Plantagenet, embrace him.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And long live thou, and these thy forward sons!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now York and Lancaster are reconcil'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Farewell, my gracious lord; I'll to my castle.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I'll keep London with my soldiers.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I to Norfolk with my followers.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Exeter, so will I.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, go not from me; I will follow thee.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Be patient, gentle queen, and I will stay.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thou hast spoke too much already; get thee gone.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, to be murder'd by his enemies.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Brother, though I be youngest, give me leave.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, I can better play the orator.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No quarrel, but a slight contention.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: About what?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Mine, boy? Not till King Henry be dead.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your right depends not on his life or death.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I took an oath that he should quietly reign.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No; God forbid your Grace should be forsworn.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I shall be, if I claim by open war.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I'll prove the contrary, if you'll hear me speak.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thou canst not, son; it is impossible.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: She shall not need; we'll meet her in the field.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, with five thousand men?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I, my lord, will bear him company.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Soldiers, away with him!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Such pity as my rapier's point affords.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I never did thee harm; why wilt thou slay me?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thy father hath.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Di faciant laudis summa sit ista tuae!         [Dies]

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yield to our mercy, proud Plantagenet.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, ay, so strives the woodcock with the gin.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: So doth the cony struggle in the net.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What would your Grace have done unto him now?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: That is my office, for my father's sake.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, stay; let's hear the orisons he makes.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, speak no more! for I have heard too much.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Say how he died, for I will hear it all.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How now, fair lords! What fare? What news abroad?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How now! what news?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, good my lord, and leave us to our fortune.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, that's my fortune too; therefore I'll stay.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Be it with resolution, then, to fight.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Are you there, butcher? O, I cannot speak!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Twas you that kill'd young Rutland, was it not?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: For God's sake, lords, give signal to the fight.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What say'st thou, Henry? Wilt thou yield the crown?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Then 'twas my turn to fly, and now 'tis thine.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You said so much before, and yet you fled.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Twas not your valour, Clifford, drove me thence.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I slew thy father; call'st thou him a child?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Stay, Edward.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Away, away! Once more, sweet lords, farewell.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Was ever son so rued a father's death?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Was ever father so bemoan'd his son?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: If so thou think'st, vex him with eager words.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thou pitied'st Rutland, I will pity thee.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Where's Captain Margaret, to fence you now?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: They mock thee, Clifford; swear as thou wast wont.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I'll stay above the hill, so both may shoot.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why linger we? let us lay hands upon him.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Forbear awhile; we'll hear a little more.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Say, what art thou that talk'st of kings and queens?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, but thou talk'st as if thou wert a king.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, so I am- in mind; and that's enough.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But, if thou be a king, where is thy crown?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But did you never swear, and break an oath?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, never such an oath; nor will not now.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Where did you dwell when I was King of England?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here in this country, where we now remain.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We are true subjects to the King, King Edward.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It were no less; but yet I'll make a pause.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside to GLOUCESTER] He knows the game; how true he keeps the wind!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside to CLARENCE] Silence!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside to GLOUCESTER] I fear her not, unless she chance to fall.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside to CLARENCE] God forbid that, for he'll take vantages.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How many children hast thou, widow, tell me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside to GLOUCESTER] I think he means to beg a child of her.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside to CLARENCE] Nay, then whip me; he'll rather give her two.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Three, my most gracious lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside] You shall have four if you'll be rul'd by him.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Twere pity they should lose their father's lands.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it, then.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Lords, give us leave; I'll try this widow's wit.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And would you not do much to do them good?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To do them good I would sustain some harm.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Then get your husband's lands, to do them good.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Therefore I came unto your Majesty.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I'll tell you how these lands are to be got.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: So shall you bind me to your Highness' service.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What service wilt thou do me if I give them?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What you command that rests in me to do.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But you will take exceptions to my boon.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, then I will do what your Grace commands.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: He plies her hard; and much rain wears the marble.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: As red as fire! Nay, then her wax must melt.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why stops my lord? Shall I not hear my task?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: An easy task; 'tis but to love a king.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: That's soon perform'd, because I am a subject.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, then, thy husband's lands I freely give thee.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The match is made; she seals it with a curtsy.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But stay thee- 'tis the fruits of love I mean.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, then you mean not as I thought you did.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Then, no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The widow likes him not; she knits her brows.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: He is the bluntest wooer in Christendom.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You cavil, widow; I did mean my queen.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Twill grieve your Grace my sons should call you father.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The ghostly father now hath done his shrift.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: When he was made a shriver, 'twas for shrift.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You'd think it strange if I should marry her.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To who, my lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, Clarence, to myself.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: That would be ten days' wonder at the least.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: That's a day longer than a wonder lasts.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By so much is the wonder in extremes.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, say, fair Queen, whence springs this deep despair?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The more I stay, the more I'll succour thee.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What's he approacheth boldly to our presence?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Aside] If that go forward, Henry's hope is done.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Injurious Margaret!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And why not Queen?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I the house of York.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But is he gracious in the people's eye?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The more that Henry was unfortunate.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To Edward, but not to the English king.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Warwick, what are thy news? And yours, fair Queen?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Mine such as fill my heart with unhop'd joys.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Mine, full of sorrow and heart's discontent.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My quarrel and this English queen's are one.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And mine, fair Lady Bona, joins with yours.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let me give humble thanks for all at once.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And his well-chosen bride.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I mind to tell him plainly what I think.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But the safer when 'tis back'd with France.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: So God help Montague as he proves true!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And Hastings as he favours Edward's cause!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Now, brother Richard, will you stand by us?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, in despite of all that shall withstand you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Fear not that, my lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, will he not to bed?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis the Lord Hastings, the King's chiefest friend.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis the more honour, because more dangerous.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Who goes there?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What are they that fly there?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Richard and Hastings. Let them go; here is the Duke.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, loss of some pitch'd battle against Warwick?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Then is my sovereign slain?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: This way, my lord; for this way lies the game.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But whither shall we then?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To Lynn, my lord; and shipt from thence to Flanders.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well guess'd, believe me; for that was my meaning.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But wherefore stay we? 'Tis no time to talk.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Huntsman, what say'st thou? Wilt thou go along?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Better do so than tarry and be hang'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come then, away; let's ha' no more ado.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And I choose Clarence only for Protector.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What else? And that succession be determin'd.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, therein Clarence shall not want his part.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It shall be done, my sovereign, with all speed.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My liege, it is young Henry, Earl of Richmond.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What news, my friend?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Unsavoury news! But how made he escape?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: True, my good lord; I know you for no less.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A wise stout captain, and soon persuaded!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Welcome, Sir john! But why come you in arms?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Away with scrupulous wit! Now arms must rule.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Long live Edward the Fourth!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let's levy men and beat him back again.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Farewell, my Hector and my Troy's true hope.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: In sign of truth, I kiss your Highness' hand.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Kissing the KING'S band] And thus I seal my truth and bid adieu.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The doubt is that he will seduce the rest.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Then Clarence is at hand; I hear his drum.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Who should that be? Belike unlook'd for friends.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: See how the surly Warwick mans the wall.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O cheerful colours! See where Oxford comes.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The gates are open, let us enter too.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Clarence, Clarence, for Lancaster!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, Clarence, come. Thou wilt if Warwick call.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Welcome, good Clarence; this is brother-like.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O passing traitor, perjur'd and unjust!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thanks, gentle Somerset; sweet Oxford, thanks.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: But he's deceiv'd; we are in readiness.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: This cheers my heart, to see your forwardness.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: For my part, I'll not trouble thee with words.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ah, that thy father had been so resolv'd!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By heaven, brat, I'll plague ye for that word.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: For God's sake, take away this captive scold.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Peace, wilful boy, or I will charm your tongue.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Untutor'd lad, thou art too malapert.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, kill me too!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Marry, and shall.             [Offers to kill her]

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done to much.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why should she live to fill the world with words?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, doth she swoon? Use means for her recovery.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What? what?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The Tower! the Tower!                         Exit

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Away with her; go, bear her hence perforce.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By heaven, I will not do thee so much ease.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good Clarence, do; sweet Clarence, do thou do it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Away, I say; I charge ye bear her hence.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Where's Richard gone?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good day, my lord. What, at your book so hard?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Think'st thou I am an executioner?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thy son I kill'd for his presumption.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks.
O, you go far!
I pray you, who, my lord?
Marry, is't.
Here, so please you.
Is he in person ready?
Ay, please your Grace.
Say not treasonous.
Faith, and so it did.
Your office, sergeant: execute it.
A monk o' th' Chartreux.
O, Nicholas Hopkins?
He.
Nay, we must longer kneel: I am suitor.
Lady mine, proceed.
Speak freely.
What was that Henton?
How know'st thou this?
I can, my liege.
Proceed.
A giant traitor!
God mend all!
There's something more would out of thee: what say'st?
What is't for?
You are young, Sir Harry Guildford.
Faith, how easy?
As easy as a down bed would afford it.
Was he mad, sir?
You cannot show me.
What's that?
Look out there, some of ye.             Exit a SERVANT
How now! what is't?
My lord!
Your Grace?
What say they?
Yes, my lord.
I fear, too much.
Whither away so fast?
Were you there?
Yes, indeed, was I.
Pray, speak what has happen'd.
You may guess quickly what.
Is he found guilty?
Yes, truly is he, and condemn'd upon't.
I am sorry for't.
So are a number more.
But, pray, how pass'd it?
After all this, how did he bear him-self
I do not think he fears death.
Let's stand close, and behold him.
Well met, my Lord Chamberlain.
Good day to both your Graces.
How is the King employ'd?
What's the cause?
Pray God he do! He'll never know himself else.
And free us from his slavery.
How sad he looks; sure, he is much afflicted.
Who's there, ha?
Pray God he be not angry.
[To NORFOLK and SUFFOLK]  We are busy; go.
[Aside to SUFFOLK]  This priest has no pride in him!
Come hither, Gardiner.                   [Walks and whispers]
Yes, he was.
Was he not held a learned man?
Yes, surely.
How! Of me?
Nay, good troth.
Yes, troth and troth. You would not be a queen!
No, not for all the riches under heaven.
No, in truth.
Now, I pray God, amen!
My honour'd lord!                       Exit LORD CHAMBERLAIN
This is strange to me.
Come, you are pleasant.
Be't so; proceed.
Say 'Henry King of England, come into the court.'
Henry King of England, &c.
Here.
Say 'Katharine Queen of England, come into the court.'
Your pleasure, madam?
Be patient yet.
Call her again.
Katharine Queen of England, come into the court.
Madam, you are call'd back.
Very well, my liege.
How now?

I can as well be hang'd as tell the manner of it. It was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown (yet 'twas not a crown neither, 'twas one of these coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once. But for all that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he offered it to him again; then he put it by again. But, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his fingers off it. And then he offered it the third time; he put it the third time by; and still as he refused it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their chopped hands and threw up their sweaty nightcaps and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked Caesar, for he swounded and fell down at it. And for mine own part, I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.

I know not what you mean by that, but I am sure Caesar fell down. If the tagrag people did not clap him and hiss him according as he pleased and displeased them, as they use to do the players in the theatre, I am no true man.

Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut. An had been a man of any occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so he fell. When he came to himself again, he said, if he had done or said anything amiss, he desired their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three or four wenches where I stood cried, "Alas, good soul!" and forgave him with all their hearts. But there's no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had stabbed their mothers, they would have done no less.

He weeds the corn, and still lets grow the weeding.
The spring is near, when green geese are a-breeding.
How follows that?
Fit in his place and time.
In reason nothing.
Something then in rhyme.
Well, sit out; go home, Berowne; adieu.
How well this yielding rescues thee from shame!
[Reads] 'Item. That no woman shall come within a mile of my court'- Hath this been proclaimed?
Four days ago.
Let's see the penalty. [Reads] '-on pain of losing her tongue.' Who devis'd this penalty?
Marry, that did I.
Sweet lord, and why?
To fright them hence with that dread penalty.
What say you, lords? Why, this was quite forgot.
Which is the Duke's own person?
This, fellow. What wouldst?
I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his Grace's farborough; but I would see his own person in flesh and blood.
This is he.
Signior Arme- Arme- commends you. There's villainy abroad; this letter will tell you more.
Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching me.
A letter from the magnificent Armado.
How low soever the matter, I hope in God for high words.
A high hope for a low heaven. God grant us patience!
To hear, or forbear hearing?
To hear meekly, sir, and to laugh moderately; or, to forbear both.
Well, sir, be it as the style shall give us cause to climb in the merriness.
In what manner?

In manner and form following, sir; all those three: I was seen with her in the manor-house, sitting with her upon the form, and taken following her into the park; which, put together, is in manner and form following. Now, sir, for the manner- it is the manner of a man to speak to a woman. For the form- in some form.
For the following, sir?
As it shall follow in my correction; and God defend the right!
Will you hear this letter with attention?
As we would hear an oracle.
Such is the simplicity of man to hearken after the flesh.
[Reads] 'Great deputy, the welkin's vicegerent and sole dominator of Navarre, my soul's earth's god and body's fost'ring patron'-
Not a word of Costard yet.
[Reads] 'So it is'-
It may be so; but if he say it is so, he is, in telling true, but so.
Peace!
Be to me, and every man that dares not fight!
No words!
Of other men's secrets, I beseech you.

[Reads] 'So it is, besieged with sable-coloured melancholy, I did commend the black oppressing humour to the most wholesome physic of thy health-giving air; and, as I am a gentleman, betook myself to walk. The time When? About the sixth hour; when beasts most graze, birds best peck, and men sit down to that nourishment which is called supper. So much for the time When. Now for the ground Which? which, I mean, I upon; it is ycleped thy park. Then for the place Where? where, I mean, I did encounter that obscene and most prepost'rous event that draweth from my snow-white pen the ebon-coloured ink which here thou viewest, beholdest, surveyest, or seest. But to the place Where? It standeth north-north-east and by east from the west corner of thy curious-knotted garden. There did I see that low-spirited swain, that base minnow of thy mirth,'
Me?
'that unlettered small-knowing soul,'
Me?
'that shallow vassal,'
Still me?
'which, as I remember, hight Costard,'
O, me!
'sorted and consorted, contrary to thy established proclaimed edict and continent canon; which, with, O, with- but with this I passion to say wherewith-'
Me, an't shall please you; I am Antony Dull.
This is not so well as I look'd for, but the best that ever I heard.
Ay, the best for the worst. But, sirrah, what say you to this?
Sir, I confess the wench.
Did you hear the proclamation?
I do confess much of the hearing it, but little of the marking of it.
It was proclaimed a year's imprisonment to be taken with a wench.
I was taken with none, sir; I was taken with a damsel.
Well, it was proclaimed damsel.
This was no damsel neither, sir; she was a virgin.
It is so varied too, for it was proclaimed virgin.
If it were, I deny her virginity; I was taken with a maid.
This 'maid' not serve your turn, sir.
This maid will serve my turn, sir.
Sir, I will pronounce your sentence: you shall fast a week with bran and water.
I had rather pray a month with mutton and porridge.
Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit grows melancholy?
A great sign, sir, that he will look sad.
Why, sadness is one and the self-same thing, dear imp.
No, no; O Lord, sir, no!
How canst thou part sadness and melancholy, my tender juvenal?
By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough signior.
Why tough signior? Why tough signior?
Why tender juvenal? Why tender juvenal?
I spoke it, tender juvenal, as a congruent epitheton appertaining to thy young days, which we may nominate tender.
And I, tough signior, as an appertinent title to your old time, which we may name tough.
Pretty and apt.
How mean you, sir? I pretty, and my saying apt? or I apt, and my saying pretty?
Thou pretty, because little.
Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt?
And therefore apt, because quick.
Speak you this in my praise, master?
In thy condign praise.
I will praise an eel with the same praise.
that an eel is ingenious?
That an eel is quick.
I do say thou art quick in answers; thou heat'st my blood.
I am answer'd, sir.
I love not to be cross'd.
[Aside] He speaks the mere contrary: crosses love not him.
I have promised to study three years with the Duke.
You may do it in an hour, sir.
Impossible.
How many is one thrice told?
I am ill at reck'ning; it fitteth the spirit of a tapster.
You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir.
I confess both; they are both the varnish of a complete man.
Then I am sure you know how much the gross sum of deuce-ace amounts to.
It doth amount to one more than two.
Which the base vulgar do call three.
True.

Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here is three studied ere ye'll thrice wink; and how easy it is to put 'years' to the word 'three,' and study three years in two words, the dancing horse will tell you.
A most fine figure!
[Aside] To prove you a cipher.

I will hereupon confess I am in love. And as it is base for a soldier to love, so am I in love with a base wench. If drawing my sword against the humour of affection would deliver me from the reprobate thought of it, I would take Desire prisoner, and ransom him to any French courtier for a new-devis'd curtsy. I think scorn to sigh; methinks I should out-swear Cupid. Comfort me, boy; what great men have been in love?
Hercules, master.
Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear boy, name more; and, sweet my child, let them be men of good repute and carriage.
Samson, master; he was a man of good carriage, great carriage, for he carried the town gates on his back like a porter; and he was in love.
O well-knit Samson! strong-jointed Samson! I do excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst me in carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was Samson's love, my dear Moth?
A woman, master.
Of what complexion?
Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of the four.
Tell me precisely of what complexion.
Of the sea-water green, sir.
Is that one of the four complexions?
As I have read, sir; and the best of them too.
Green, indeed, is the colour of lovers; but to have a love of that colour, methinks Samson had small reason for it. He surely affected her for her wit.
It was so, sir; for she had a green wit.
My love is most immaculate white and red.
Most maculate thoughts, master, are mask'd under such colours.
Define, define, well-educated infant.
My father's wit my mother's tongue assist me!
Sweet invocation of a child; most pretty, and pathetical!
Is there not a ballad, boy, of the King and the Beggar?
The world was very guilty of such a ballad some three ages since; but I think now 'tis not to be found; or if it were, it would neither serve for the writing nor the tune.
[Aside] To be whipt; and yet a better love than my master.
Sing, boy; my spirit grows heavy in love.
And that's great marvel, loving a light wench.
I say, sing.

Sir, the Duke's pleasure is that you keep Costard safe; and you must suffer him to take no delight nor no penance; but 'a must fast three days a week. For this damsel, I must keep her at the park; she is allow'd for the day-woman. Fare you well.
I do betray myself with blushing. Maid!
Man!
I will visit thee at the lodge.
That's hereby.
I know where it is situate.
Lord, how wise you are!
I will tell thee wonders.
With that face?
I love thee.
So I heard you say.
And so, farewell.
Fair weather after you!
Come, Jaquenetta, away.             Exit with JAQUENETTA
Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offences ere thou be pardoned.
Well, sir, I hope when I do it I shall do it on a full stomach.
Thou shalt be heavily punished.
I am more bound to you than your fellows, for they are but lightly rewarded.
Take away this villain; shut him up.
Come, you transgressing slave, away.
Let me not be pent up, sir; I will fast, being loose.
No, sir; that were fast, and loose. Thou shalt to prison.
Well, if ever I do see the merry days of desolation that I have seen, some shall see.
What shall some see?
Proud of employment, willingly I go.
Lord Longaville is one.
Know you the man?
Some merry mocking lord, belike; is't so?
They say so most that most his humours know.
Now, what admittance, lord?
Fair Princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.
'Fair' I give you back again; and 'welcome' I have not yet. The roof of this court is too high to be yours, and welcome to the wide fields too base to be mine.
You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.
I will be welcome then; conduct me thither.
Hear me, dear lady: I have sworn an oath-
Our Lady help my lord! He'll be forsworn.
Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.
Why, will shall break it; will, and nothing else.
Your ladyship is ignorant what it is.
Madam, I will, if suddenly I may.
Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?
Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?
I know you did.
How needless was it then to ask the question!
You must not be so quick.
'Tis long of you, that spur me with such questions.
Your wit 's too hot, it speeds too fast, 'twill tire.
Not till it leave the rider in the mire.
What time o' day?
The hour that fools should ask.
Now fair befall your mask!
Fair fall the face it covers!
And send you many lovers!
Amen, so you be none.
Nay, then will I be gone.
Satisfy me so.
Lady, I will commend you to mine own heart.
I would you heard it groan.
Is the fool sick?
Sick at the heart.
Alack, let it blood.
Would that do it good?
My physic says 'ay.'
Will YOU prick't with your eye?
No point, with my knife.
Now, God save thy life!
And yours from long living!
I cannot stay thanksgiving.                [Retiring]
Sir, I pray you, a word: what lady is that same?
The heir of Alencon, Katharine her name.
A gallant lady! Monsieur, fare you well.          Exit
I beseech you a word: what is she in the white?
A woman sometimes, an you saw her in the light.
Perchance light in the light. I desire her name.
She hath but one for herself; to desire that were a shame.
Pray you, sir, whose daughter?
Her mother's, I have heard.
God's blessing on your beard!
Not unlike, sir; that may be.           Exit LONGAVILLE
What's her name in the cap?
Rosaline, by good hap.
Is she wedded or no?
To her will, sir, or so.
You are welcome, sir; adieu!
And every jest but a word.
It was well done of you to take him at his word.
I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.
Two hot sheeps, marry!
You sheep and I pasture- shall that finish the jest?
So you grant pasture for me.     [Offering to kiss her]
Belonging to whom?
To my fortunes and me.
With what?
With that which we lovers entitle 'affected.'
Your reason?
Come, to our pavilion. Boyet is dispos'd.
Thou art an old love-monger, and speakest skilfully.
He is Cupid's grandfather, and learns news of him.
Then was Venus like her mother; for her father is but grim.
Do you hear, my mad wenches?
No.
What, then; do you see?
Ay, our way to be gone.
Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years, take this key, give enlargement to the swain, bring him festinately hither; I must employ him in a letter to my love.
Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?
How meanest thou? Brawling in French?
How hast thou purchased this experience?
By my penny of observation.
But O- but O-
The hobby-horse is forgot.
Call'st thou my love 'hobby-horse'?
No, master; the hobby-horse is but a colt, and your love perhaps a hackney. But have you forgot your love?
Almost I had.
Negligent student! learn her by heart.
By heart and in heart, boy.
And out of heart, master; all those three I will prove.
What wilt thou prove?

A man, if I live; and this, by, in, and without, upon the instant. By heart you love her, because your heart cannot come by her; in heart you love her, because your heart is in love with her; and out of heart you love her, being out of heart that you cannot enjoy her.
I am all these three.
And three times as much more, and yet nothing at all.
Fetch hither the swain; he must carry me a letter.
A message well sympathiz'd- a horse to be ambassador for an ass.
Ha, ha, what sayest thou?
Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse, for he is very slow-gaited. But I go.
The way is but short; away.
As swift as lead, sir.
Minime, honest master; or rather, master, no.
I say lead is slow.
Thump, then, and I flee.                            Exit
A wonder, master! here's a costard broken in a shin.
Some enigma, some riddle; come, thy l'envoy; begin.

By virtue thou enforcest laughter; thy silly thought, my spleen; the heaving of my lungs provokes me to ridiculous smiling. O, pardon me, my stars! Doth the inconsiderate take salve for l'envoy, and the word 'l'envoy' for a salve?
Do the wise think them other? Is not l'envoy a salve?
I will add the l'envoy. Say the moral again.
A good l'envoy, ending in the goose; would you desire more?
Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin?
But tell me: how was there a costard broken in a shin?
I will tell you sensibly.
We will talk no more of this matter.
Till there be more matter in the shin.
Sirrah Costard. I will enfranchise thee.
O, Marry me to one Frances! I smell some l'envoy, some goose, in this.
By my sweet soul, I mean setting thee at liberty, enfreedoming thy person; thou wert immured, restrained, captivated, bound.
True, true; and now you will be my purgation, and let me loose.

I give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance; and, in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but this: bear this significant [giving a letter] to the country maid Jaquenetta; there is remuneration, for the best ward of mine honour is rewarding my dependents. Moth, follow.                  Exit
Like the sequel, I. Signior Costard, adieu.
My good knave Costard, exceedingly well met!
Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon may a man buy for a remuneration?
What is a remuneration?
Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.
Why, then, three-farthing worth of silk.
I thank your worship. God be wi' you!
When would you have it done, sir?
This afternoon.
Well, I will do it, sir; fare you well.
Thou knowest not what it is.
I shall know, sir, when I have done it.
Why, villain, thou must know first.
I will come to your worship to-morrow morning.
I know not; but I think it was not he.
Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.
Yes, madam, fair.
Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.
Here comes a member of the commonwealth.
God dig-you-den all! Pray you, which is the head lady?
Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that have no heads.
Which is the greatest lady, the highest?
The thickest and the tallest.
What's your will, sir? What's your will?
I am much deceived but I remember the style.
Else your memory is bad, going o'er it erewhile.
I told you: my lord.
To whom shouldst thou give it?
From my lord to my lady.
From which lord to which lady?
Who is the shooter? who is the shooter?
Shall I teach you to know?
Ay, my continent of beauty.
Well then, I am the shooter.
And who is your deer?
You Still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes at the brow.
But she herself is hit lower. Have I hit her now?
Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that was a man when King Pepin of France was a little boy, as touching the hit it?
By my troth, most pleasant! How both did fit it!
A mark marvellous well shot; for they both did hit it.
Wide o' the bow-hand! I' faith, your hand is out.
Indeed, 'a must shoot nearer, or he'll ne'er hit the clout.
An if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.
Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.
Come, come, you talk greasily; your lips grow foul.
She's too hard for you at pricks, sir; challenge her to bowl.
Very reverent sport, truly; and done in the testimony of a good conscience.

The deer was, as you know, sanguis, in blood; ripe as the pomewater, who now hangeth like a jewel in the ear of caelo, the sky, the welkin, the heaven; and anon falleth like a crab on the face of terra, the soil, the land, the earth.
Truly, Master Holofernes, the epithets are sweetly varied, like a scholar at the least; but, sir, I assure ye it was a buck of the first head.
Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.
'Twas not a haud credo; 'twas a pricket.

Most barbarous intimation! yet a kind of insinuation, as it were, in via, in way, of explication; facere, as it were, replication, or rather, ostentare, to show, as it were, his inclination, after his undressed, unpolished, uneducated, unpruned, untrained, or rather unlettered, or ratherest unconfirmed fashion, to insert again my haud credo for a deer.
I Said the deer was not a haud credo; 'twas a pricket.
Dictynna, goodman Dull; Dictynna, goodman Dull.
What is Dictynna?
A title to Phoebe, to Luna, to the moon.
'Tis true, indeed; the collusion holds in the exchange.
God comfort thy capacity! I say th' allusion holds in the exchange.
And I say the polusion holds in the exchange; for the moon is never but a month old; and I say, beside, that 'twas a pricket that the Princess kill'd.
Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal epitaph on the death of the deer? And, to humour the ignorant, call the deer the Princess kill'd a pricket.
Perge, good Master Holofernes, perge, so it shall please you to abrogate scurrility.
A rare talent!
[Aside] If a talent be a claw, look how he claws him with a talent.

This is a gift that I have, simple, simple; a foolish extravagant spirit, full of forms, figures, shapes, objects, ideas, apprehensions, motions, revolutions. These are begot in the ventricle of memory, nourish'd in the womb of pia mater, and delivered upon the mellowing of occasion. But the gift is good in those in whom it is acute, and I am thankful for it.
Sir, I praise the Lord for you, and so may my parishioners; for their sons are well tutor'd by you, and their daughters profit very greatly under you. You are a good member of the commonwealth.
God give you good morrow, Master Person.
Master Person, quasi pers-one. And if one should be pierc'd which is the one?
Marry, Master Schoolmaster, he that is likest to a hogshead.
Piercing a hogshead! A good lustre of conceit in a turf of earth; fire enough for a flint, pearl enough for a swine; 'tis pretty; it is well.
Good Master Parson, be so good as read me this letter; it was given me by Costard, and sent me from Don Armado. I beseech you read it.
Ay, sir, and very learned.
Let me hear a staff, a stanze, a verse; lege, domine.

You find not the apostrophas, and so miss the accent: let me supervise the canzonet. Here are only numbers ratified; but, for the elegancy, facility, and golden cadence of poesy, caret. Ovidius Naso was the man. And why, indeed, 'Naso' but for smelling out the odoriferous flowers of fancy, the jerks of invention? Imitari is nothing: so doth the hound his master, the ape his keeper, the tired horse his rider. But, damosella virgin, was this directed to you?
Ay, sir, from one Monsieur Berowne, one of the strange queen's lords.

I will overglance the superscript: 'To the snow-white hand of the most beauteous Lady Rosaline.' I will look again on the intellect of the letter, for the nomination of the party writing to the person written unto: 'Your Ladyship's in all desired employment, Berowne.' Sir Nathaniel, this Berowne is one of the votaries with the King; and here he hath framed a letter to a sequent of the stranger queen's which accidentally, or by the way of progression, hath miscarried. Trip and go, my sweet; deliver this paper into the royal hand of the King; it may concern much. Stay not thy compliment; I forgive thy duty. Adieu.
Good Costard, go with me. Sir, God save your life!
Sir, you have done this in the fear of God, very religiously; and, as a certain father saith-
Marvellous well for the pen.

I do dine to-day at the father's of a certain pupil of mine; where, if, before repast, it shall please you to gratify the table with a grace, I will, on my privilege I have with the parents of the foresaid child or pupil, undertake your ben venuto; where I will prove those verses to be very unlearned, neither savouring of poetry, wit, nor invention. I beseech your society.
And thank you too; for society, saith the text, is the happiness of life.
Ay me!
Shot, by heaven! Proceed, sweet Cupid; thou hast thump'd him with thy bird-bolt under the left pap. In faith, secrets!
Now, in thy likeness, one more fool appear!
Ay me, I am forsworn!
Why, he comes in like a perjure, wearing papers.
In love, I hope; sweet fellowship in shame!
One drunkard loves another of the name.
Am I the first that have been perjur'd so?
O most divine Kate!
O most profane coxcomb!
By heaven, the wonder in a mortal eye!
By earth, she is not, corporal: there you lie.
Her amber hairs for foul hath amber quoted.
An amber-colour'd raven was well noted.
As upright as the cedar.
As fair as day.
Ay, as some days; but then no sun must shine.
O that I had my wish!
And I had mine!
And I mine too,.good Lord!
Amen, so I had mine! Is not that a good word?
Once more I'll read the ode that I have writ.
Once more I'll mark how love can vary wit.
God bless the King!
What present hast thou there?
Some certain treason.
What makes treason here?
Nay, it makes nothing, sir.
Of Costard.
Where hadst thou it?
How now! What is in you? Why dost thou tear it?
A toy, my liege, a toy! Your Grace needs not fear it.
What?
Hence, sirs, away.
What, did these rent lines show some love of thine?
By heaven, thy love is black as ebony.
To look like her are chimney-sweepers black.
And since her time are colliers counted bright.
And Ethiopes of their sweet complexion crack.
Dark needs no candles now, for dark is light.
I'll prove her fair, or talk till doomsday here.
No devil will fright thee then so much as she.
I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.
But what of this? Are we not all in love?
Nothing so sure; and thereby all forsworn.
Ay, marry, there; some flattery for this evil.
Some salve for perjury.
Saint Cupid, then! and, soldiers, to the field!
Satis quod sufficit.

I praise God for you, sir. Your reasons at dinner have been sharp and sententious; pleasant without scurrility, witty without affection, audacious without impudency, learned without opinion, and strange without heresy. I did converse this quondam day with a companion of the King's who is intituled, nominated, or called, Don Adriano de Armado.

Novi hominem tanquam te. His humour is lofty, his discourse peremptory, his tongue filed, his eye ambitious, his gait majestical and his general behaviour vain, ridiculous, and thrasonical. He is too picked, too spruce, too affected, too odd, as it were, too peregrinate, as I may call it.
Laus Deo, bone intelligo.
Videsne quis venit?
Video, et gaudeo.
[To MOTH] Chirrah!
Quare 'chirrah,' not 'sirrah'?
Men of peace, well encount'red.
Most military sir, salutation.
[Aside to COSTARD] They have been at a great feast of languages and stol'n the scraps.

O, they have liv'd long on the alms-basket of words. I marvel thy master hath not eaten thee for a word, for thou are not so long by the head as honorificabilitudinitatibus; thou art easier swallowed than a flap-dragon.
Peace! the peal begins.
[To HOLOFERNES] Monsieur, are you not lett'red?
Yes, yes; he teaches boys the hornbook. What is a, b, spelt backward with the horn on his head?
Ba, pueritia, with a horn added.
Ba, most silly sheep with a horn. You hear his learning.
Quis, quis, thou consonant?
The third of the five vowels, if You repeat them; or the fifth, if I.
I will repeat them: a, e, I-
The sheep; the other two concludes it: o, U.
Now, by the salt wave of the Mediterraneum, a sweet touch, a quick venue of wit- snip, snap, quick and home. It rejoiceth my intellect. True wit!
Offer'd by a child to an old man; which is wit-old.
What is the figure? What is the figure?
Horns.
Thou disputes like an infant; go whip thy gig.
Lend me your horn to make one, and I will whip about your infamy circum circa- a gig of a cuckold's horn.

An I had but one penny in the world, thou shouldst have it to buy ginger-bread. Hold, there is the very remuneration I had of thy master, thou halfpenny purse of wit, thou pigeon-egg of discretion. O, an the heavens were so pleased that thou wert but my bastard, what a joyful father wouldst thou make me! Go to; thou hast it ad dunghill, at the fingers' ends, as they say.
O, I smell false Latin; 'dunghill' for unguem.
Arts-man, preambulate; we will be singuled from the barbarous. Do you not educate youth at the charge-house on the top of the mountain?
Or mons, the hill.
At your sweet pleasure, for the mountain.
I do, sans question.
Sir, it is the King's most sweet pleasure and affection to congratulate the Princess at her pavilion, in the posteriors of this day; which the rude multitude call the afternoon.
The posterior of the day, most generous sir, is liable, congruent, and measurable, for the afternoon. The word is well cull'd, chose, sweet, and apt, I do assure you, sir, I do assure.
Where will you find men worthy enough to present them?
Joshua, yourself; myself, Alexander; this gallant gentleman, Judas Maccabaeus; this swain, because of his great limb or joint, shall pass Pompey the Great; the page, Hercules.
Shall I have audience? He shall present Hercules in minority: his enter and exit shall be strangling a snake; and I will have an apology for that purpose.
An excellent device! So, if any of the audience hiss, you may cry 'Well done, Hercules; now thou crushest the snake!' That is the way to make an offence gracious, though few have the grace to do it.
For the rest of the Worthies?
I will play three myself.
Thrice-worthy gentleman!
Shall I tell you a thing?
We attend.
We will have, if this fadge not, an antic. I beseech you, follow.
Via, goodman Dull! Thou has spoken no word all this while.
