ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I pray you, pardon me; I cannot speak.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What's the matter?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, past all surgery.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Marry, heaven forbid!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Reputation, reputation, reputation! O, I have lost my reputation! I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is bestial. My reputation, Iago, my reputation!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: As I am an honest man, I thought you had received some bodily wound; there is more sense in that than in reputation. Reputation is an idle and most false imposition; oft got without merit and lost without deserving. You have lost no reputation at all, unless you repute yourself such a loser. What, man! there are ways to recover the general again. You are but now cast in his mood, a punishment more in policy than in malice; even so as one would beat his offenseless dog to affright an imperious lion. Sue to him again, and he's yours.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I will rather sue to be despised than to deceive so good a commander with so slight, so drunken, and so indiscreet an officer. Drunk? and speak parrot? and squabble? swagger? swear? and discourse fustian with one's own shadow? O thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let us call thee devil!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I know not.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is't possible?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly; a quarrel, but nothing wherefore. O God, that men should put an enemy in their mouths to steal away their brains! that we should, with joy, pleasance, revel, and applause, transform ourselves into beasts!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It hath pleased the devil drunkenness to give place to the devil wrath: one unperfectness shows me another, to make me frankly despise myself.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, you are too severe a moraler. As the time, the place, and the condition of this country stands, I could heartily wish this had not befallen; but since it is as it is, mend it for your own good.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I will ask him for my place again; he shall tell me I am a drunkard! Had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all. To be now a sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently a beast! O strange! Every inordinate cup is unblest, and the ingredient is a devil.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well used. Exclaim no more against it. And, good lieutenant, I think you think I love you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I have well approved it, sir. I drunk!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You or any man living may be drunk at some time, man. I'll tell you what you shall do. Our general's wife is now the general. I may say so in this respect, for that he hath devoted and given up himself to the contemplation, mark, and denotement of her parts and graces. Confess yourself freely to her; importune her help to put you in your place again. She is of so free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition, she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested. This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter; and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You advise me well.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I think it freely; and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me. I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me here.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You are in the right. Good night, lieutenant, I must to the watch.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good night, honest Iago.                              Exit.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, masters, have your instruments been in Naples, that they speak i' the nose thus?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Are these, I pray you, wind instruments?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, thereby hangs a tail.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Whereby hangs a tale, sir?

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Marry, sir, by many a wind instrument that I know. But, masters, here's money for you; and the general so likes your music, that he desires you, for love's sake, to make no more noise with it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well, sir, we will not.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: If you have any music that may not be heard, to't again; but, as they say, to hear music the general does not greatly care.

In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: We have none such, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Will you sup there?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Faith, I intend so.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well, I may chance to see you, for I would very fain speak with you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Prithee, come; will you?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Go to; say no more.                              Exit Cassio.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Advancing.] How shall I murther him, Iago?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O Iago!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And did you see the handkerchief?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Was that mine?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yours, by this hand. And to see how he prizes the foolish woman your wife! She gave it him, and he hath given it his whore.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I would have him nine years akilling. A fine woman! a fair woman! a sweet woman!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, you must forget that.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, that's not your way.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Hang her! I do but say what she is. So delicate with her needle, an admirable musician. O, she will sing the savageness out of a bear. Of so high and plenteous wit and invention-

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: She's the worse for all this.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, a thousand, a thousand times. And then, of so gentle a condition!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, too gentle.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for, if it touch not you, it comes near nobody.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I will chop her into messes. Cuckold me!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, 'tis foul in her.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: With mine officer!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: That's fouler.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Get me some poison, Iago, this night. I'll not expostulate with her, lest her body and beauty unprovide my mind again. This night, Iago.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Do it not with poison, strangle her in her bed, even the bed she hath contaminated.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good, good, the justice of it pleases, very good.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker. You shall hear more by midnight.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Excellent good. [A trumpet within.] What trumpet is that same?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: God save the worthy general!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: With all my heart, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And what's the news, good cousin Lodovico?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I thank you. How does Lieutenant Cassio?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Lives, sir.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Are you sure of that?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Reads.] "This fail you not to do, as you will-"

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Fire and brimstone!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Are you wise?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, is he angry?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By my troth, I am glad on't.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Indeed!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am glad to see you mad.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, sweet Othello?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Devil!                                        Strikes her.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I have not deserved this.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: [Going.] I will not stay to offend you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Mistress!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What would you with her, sir?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Who, I, my lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: He is much changed.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Are his wits safe? Is he not light of brain?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, strike his wife!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You have seen nothing, then?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, did they never whisper?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Never, my lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nor send you out o' the way?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Never.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Never, my lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: That's strange.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, what is your will?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Pray, chuck, come hither.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What is your pleasure?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What horrible fancy's this?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, what art thou?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your wife, my lord, your true and loyal wife.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Heaven doth truly know it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: To whom, my lord? with whom? how am I false?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O Desdemona! Away! away! away!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: By heaven, you do me wrong.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Are not you a strumpet?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What, not a whore?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: No, as I shall be saved.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is't possible?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, heaven forgive us!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Faith, half asleep.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Good madam, what's the matter with my lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: With who?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, with my lord, madam.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Who is thy lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: He that is yours, sweet lady.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What is your pleasure, madam? How is't with you?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What's the matter, lady?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Am I that name, Iago?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What name, fair lady?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Such as she says my lord did say I was.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why did he so?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I do not know; I am sure I am none such.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Do not weep, do not weep. Alas the day!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It is my wretched fortune.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Nay, heaven doth know.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Fie, there is no such man; it is impossible.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: If any such there be, heaven pardon him!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Speak within door.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You are a fool; go to.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: If 'twere no other-

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I do not find that thou dealest justly with me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: What in the contrary?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Every day thou daffest me with some device, Iago; and rather, as it seems to me now, keepest from me all conveniency than suppliest me with the least advantage of hope. I will indeed no longer endure it; nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what already I have foolishly suffered.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Will you hear me, Roderigo?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Faith, I have heard too much, for your words and performances are no kin together.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You charge me most unjustly.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: With nought but truth. I have wasted myself out of my means. The jewels you have had from me to deliver to Desdemona would half have corrupted a votarist. You have told me she hath received them and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden respect and acquaintance; but I find none.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well, go to, very well.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Very well! go to! I cannot go to, man; nor 'tis not very well. By this hand, I say 'tis very scurvy, and begin to find myself fopped in it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Very well.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I tell you 'tis not very well. I will make myself known to Desdemona. If she will return me my jewels, I will give over my suit and repent my unlawful solicitation; if not, assure yourself I will seek satisfaction of you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You have said now.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, now I see there's mettle in thee; and even from this instant do build on thee a better opinion than ever before. Give me thy hand, Roderigo. Thou hast taken against me a most just exception; but yet, I protest, have dealt most directly in thy affair.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It hath not appeared.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your suspicion is not without wit and judgement. But, Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which I have greater reason to believe now than ever, I mean purpose, courage, and valor, this night show it; if thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona, take me from this world with treachery and devise engines for my life.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Well, what is it? Is it within reason and compass?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Is that true? Why then Othello and Desdemona return again to Venice.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How do you mean, removing of him?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello's place; knocking out his brains.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: And that you would have me to do?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right. He sups tonight with a harlotry, and thither will I go to him. He knows not yet of his honorable fortune. If you will watch his going thence, which his will fashion to fall out between twelve and one, you may take him at your pleasure; I will be near to second your attempt, and he shall fall between us. Come, stand not amazed at it, but go along with me; I will show you such a necessity in his death that you shall think yourself bound to put it on him. It is now high supper-time, and the night grows to waste. About it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I will hear further reason for this.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, pardon me; 'twill do me good to walk.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Madam, good night; I humbly thank your ladyship.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Your honor is most welcome.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Get you to bed on the instant; I will be returned forthwith. Dismiss your attendant there; look it be done.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: How goes it now? He looks gentler than he did.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Dismiss me?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I would you had never seen him!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Come, come, you talk.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Shall I go fetch your nightgown?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A very handsome man.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: He speaks well.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: It's the wind.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: 'Tis neither here nor there.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: There be some such, no question.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE TRAGEDY OF OTHELLO, MOOR OF VENICE

I cannot tell; but I had as lief take her dowry with this condition: to be whipp'd at the high cross every morning.
Ay, marry, am I, sir, and now 'tis plotted.
I have it, Tranio.
Tell me thine first.
It is. May it be done?
I, sir? Ne'er a whit.
The better for him; would I were so too!
My lord, you nod; you do not mind the play.
Yes, by Saint Anne do I. A good matter, surely; comes there any more of it?
My lord, 'tis but begun.
Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.
Knock you here, sir? Why, sir, what am I, sir, that I should knock you here, sir?
Help, masters, help! My master is mad.
How now! what's the matter? My old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio! How do you all at Verona?
Knock at the gate? O heavens! Spake you not these words plain: 'Sirrah knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly'? And come you now with 'knocking at the gate'?
Sirrah, be gone, or talk not, I advise you.

I pray you, sir, let him go while the humour lasts. O' my word, and she knew him as well as I do, she would think scolding would do little good upon him. She may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so. Why, that's nothing; and he begin once, he'll rail in his rope-tricks. I'll tell you what, sir: an she stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in her face, and so disfigure her with it that she shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat. You know him not, sir.
Here's no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together! Master, master, look about you. Who goes there, ha?
Peace, Grumio! It is the rival of my love. Petruchio, stand by awhile.
O this learning, what a thing it is!
O this woodcock, what an ass it is!
Peace, sirrah!
Beloved of me- and that my deeds shall prove.
And that his bags shall prove.
No, say'st me so, friend? What countryman?
Will I live?
Will he woo her? Ay, or I'll hang her.
For he fears none.
And so we will- provided that he win her.
He that has the two fair daughters; is't he you mean?
Even he, Biondello.
Hark you, sir, you mean not her to-
Perhaps him and her, sir; what have you to do?
Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.
I love no chiders, sir. Biondello, let's away.
[Aside]  Well begun, Tranio.
And if I be, sir, is it any offence?
No; if without more words you will get you hence.
But so is not she.
For what reason, I beseech you?
That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio.
What, this gentleman will out-talk us all!
Sir, give him head; I know he'll prove a jade.
Hortensio, to what end are all these words?
Sir, sir, the first's for me; let her go by.
O excellent motion! Fellows, let's be gone.
Minion, thou liest. Is't not Hortensio?
Good morrow, neighbour Baptista.
I have a daughter, sir, call'd Katherina.
You are too blunt; go to it orderly.
I know him well; you are welcome for his sake.
O, pardon me, Signior Gremio! I would fain be doing.
Lucentio is your name? Of whence, I pray?
Of Pisa, sir; son to Vincentio.
How now, my friend! Why dost thou look so pale?
For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.
What, will my daughter prove a good musician?
Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?
Why, what's a moveable?
A join'd-stool.
Thou hast hit it. Come, sit on me.
Asses are made to bear, and so are you.
Women are made to bear, and so are you.
No such jade as you, if me you mean.
Should be! should- buzz!
Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.
O, slow-wing'd turtle, shall a buzzard take thee?
Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.
Come, come, you wasp; i' faith, you are too angry.
If I be waspish, best beware my sting.
My remedy is then to pluck it out.
Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies.
In his tongue.
Whose tongue?
Yours, if you talk of tales; and so farewell.
That I'll try.                    [She strikes him]
I swear I'll cuff you, if you strike again.
A herald, Kate? O, put me in thy books!
What is your crest- a coxcomb?
A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.
No cock of mine: you crow too like a craven.
Nay, come, Kate, come; you must not look so sour.
It is my fashion, when I see a crab.
Why, here's no crab; and therefore look not sour.
There is, there is.
Then show it me.
Had I a glass I would.
What, you mean my face?
Well aim'd of such a young one.
Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.
Yet you are wither'd.
'Tis with cares.
I care not.
Nay, hear you, Kate- in sooth, you scape not so.
I chafe you, if I tarry; let me go.
Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.
Where did you study all this goodly speech?
It is extempore, from my mother wit.
A witty mother! witless else her son.
Am I not wise?
Yes, keep you warm.
Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?
Why, how now, daughter Katherine, in your dumps?
I'll see thee hang'd on Sunday first.
Hark, Petruchio; she says she'll see thee hang'd first.
Is this your speeding? Nay, then good-night our part!
Amen, say we; we will be witnesses.
Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?
The gain I seek is quiet in the match.
Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.
Greybeard, thy love doth freeze.
But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.
That's but a cavil; he is old, I young.
And may not young men die as well as old?
Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.
You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?
That will be never- tune your instrument.
Where left we last?
Construe them.
Madam, my instrument's in tune.
Let's hear. O fie! the treble jars.
Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.
Madam, 'tis now in tune.
All but the bass.
In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.
Why, I am past my gamut long ago.
Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.
Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.
Is it new and old too? How may that be?
Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchio's coming?
Is he come?
Why, no, sir.
What then?
He is coming.
When will he be here?
When he stands where I am and sees you there.
But, say, what to thine old news?

Why, Petruchio is coming- in a new hat and an old jerkin; a pair of old breeches thrice turn'd; a pair of boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled, another lac'd; an old rusty sword ta'en out of the town armoury, with a broken hilt, and chapeless; with two broken points; his horse hipp'd, with an old motley saddle and stirrups of no kindred; besides, possess'd with the glanders and like to mose in the chine, troubled with the lampass, infected with the fashions, full of windgalls, sped with spavins, rayed with the yellows, past cure of the fives, stark spoil'd with the staggers, begnawn with the bots, sway'd in the back and shoulder-shotten, near-legg'd before, and with a half-cheek'd bit, and a head-stall of sheep's leather which, being restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been often burst, and now repaired with knots; one girth six times piec'd, and a woman's crupper of velure, which hath two letters for her name fairly set down in studs, and here and there piec'd with pack-thread.
Who comes with him?

O, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparison'd like the horse- with a linen stock on one leg and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gart'red with a red and blue list; an old hat, and the humour of forty fancies prick'd in't for a feather; a monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's lackey.
I am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.
Why, sir, he comes not.
Didst thou not say he comes?
Who? that Petruchio came?
Ay, that Petruchio came.
No, sir; I say his horse comes with him on his back.
Why, that's all one.
Come, where be these gallants? Who's at home?
You are welcome, sir.
And yet I come not well.
And yet you halt not.
Not I, believe me; thus I'll visit her.

As willingly as e'er I came from school.
And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?
Curster than she? Why, 'tis impossible.
Why, he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.
Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.
What said the wench, when he rose again?
Is't possible you will away to-night?
Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.

Let me entreat you.

Let me entreat you.

Grumio, my horse.
Ay, sir, they be ready; the oats have eaten the horses.
O Kate, content thee; prithee be not angry.
Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.
Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.

Of all mad matches, never was the like.
Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?
That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.
I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.
Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?
Who is that calls so coldly?
A piece of ice. If thou doubt it, thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck. A fire, good Curtis.
Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?
O, ay, Curtis, ay; and therefore fire, fire; cast on no water.
Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?
She was, good Curtis, before this frost; but thou know'st winter tames man, woman, and beast; for it hath tam'd my old master, and my new mistress, and myself, fellow Curtis.
Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.

Am I but three inches? Why, thy horn is a foot, and so long am I at the least. But wilt thou make a fire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress, whose hand- she being now at hand- thou shalt soon feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?
I prithee, good Grumio, tell me how goes the world?
A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine; and therefore fire. Do thy duty, and have thy duty, for my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.
There's fire ready; and therefore, good Grumio, the news?
Why, 'Jack boy! ho, boy!' and as much news as thou wilt.
Come, you are so full of cony-catching!
All ready; and therefore, I pray thee, news.
First know my horse is tired; my master and mistress fall'n out.
How?
Out of their saddles into the dirt; and thereby hangs a tale.
Let's ha't, good Grumio.
Lend thine ear.
Here.
There.                                  [Striking him]
This 'tis to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.
Both of one horse?
What's that to thee?
Why, a horse.

Tell thou the tale. But hadst thou not cross'd me, thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell and she under her horse; thou shouldst have heard in how miry a place, how she was bemoil'd, how he left her with the horse upon her, how he beat me because her horse stumbled, how she waded through the dirt to pluck him off me, how he swore, how she pray'd that never pray'd before, how I cried, how the horses ran away, how her bridle was burst, how I lost my crupper- with many things of worthy memory, which now shall die in oblivion, and thou return unexperienc'd to thy grave.
By this reck'ning he is more shrew than she.
They are.
Call them forth.
Do you hear, ho? You must meet my master, to countenance my mistress.
Why, she hath a face of her own.
Who knows not that?
Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.
I call them forth to credit her.
Welcome home, Grumio!
How now, Grumio!
What, Grumio!
Fellow Grumio!
How now, old lad!
Welcome, you!- how now, you!- what, you!- fellow, you!- and thus much for greeting. Now, my spruce companions, is all ready, and all things neat?
All things is ready. How near is our master?
Here, here, sir; here, sir.
Here, sir; as foolish as I was before.
Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.
Ay.
Who brought it?
I.
Peter, didst ever see the like?
Where is he?
Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?
What, master, read you, First resolve me that.
I read that I profess, 'The Art to Love.'
And may you prove, sir, master of your art!
Tranio, you jest; but have you both forsworn me?
Mistress, we have.
Then we are rid of Licio.
God give him joy!
Ay, and he'll tame her.
He says so, Tranio.
Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.
The taming-school! What, is there such a place?
What is he, Biondello?
And what of him, Tranio?
God save you, sir!
What countryman, I pray?
Of Mantua.
My life, sir! How, I pray? For that goes hard.
Among them know you one Vincentio?
[Aside]  As much as an apple doth an oyster, and all one.
No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.
What say you to a neat's foot?
'Tis passing good; I prithee let me have it.
I like it well; good Grumio, fetch it me.
A dish that I do love to feed upon.
Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.
Why then the beef, and let the mustard rest.
Then both, or one, or anything thou wilt.
Why then the mustard without the beef.
How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?
Mistress, what cheer?
Faith, as cold as can be.
I pray you, let it stand.
I thank you, sir.
Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.
[Aside]  That will not be in haste.
[Aside]  I see she's like to have neither cap nor gown.
Why, true; he means to make a puppet of thee.
She says your worship means to make a puppet of her.
I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.
But how did you desire it should be made?
Marry, sir, with needle and thread.
But did you not request to have it cut?
Thou hast fac'd many things.
I have.
Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify.
Read it.
The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.
[Reads]  'Imprimis, a loose-bodied gown'-
Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sew me in the skirts of it and beat me to death with a bottom of brown bread; I said a gown.
Proceed.
[Reads]  'With a small compass'd cape'-
I confess the cape.
[Reads]  'With a trunk sleeve'-
I confess two sleeves.
[Reads]  'The sleeves curiously cut.'
Ay, there's the villainy.
Error i' th' bill, sir; error i' th' bill! I commanded the sleeves should be cut out, and sew'd up again; and that I'll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.
This is true that I say; an I had thee in place where, thou shouldst know it.
I am for thee straight; take thou the bill, give me thy meteyard, and spare not me.
God-a-mercy, Grumio! Then he shall have no odds.
Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.
You are i' th' right, sir; 'tis for my mistress.
Go, take it up unto thy master's use.
Villain, not for thy life! Take up my mistress' gown for thy master's use!
Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?
Sir, this is the house; please it you that I call?
Tut, fear not me.
But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?
I pray the gods she may, with all my heart.
Cambio.
What say'st thou, Biondello?
You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?
Biondello, what of that?
Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.
I pray thee moralize them.
Then thus: Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.
And what of him?
His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.
And then?
The old priest at Saint Luke's church is at your command at all hours.
And what of all this?
Hear'st thou, Biondello?

I cannot tarry. I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir; and so adieu, sir. My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke's to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.
The moon? The sun! It is not moonlight now.
I say it is the moon that shines so bright.
I know it is the sun that shines so bright.
Say as he says, or we shall never go.
I say it is the moon.
I know it is the moon.
Nay, then you lie; it is the blessed sun.
Petruchio, go thy ways, the field is won.
'A will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.
What is his name?
Lucentio, gentle sir.
I do assure thee, father, so it is.
Softly and swiftly, sir, for the priest is ready.
I fly, Biondello; but they may chance to need the at home, therefore leave us.
What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?
Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?
He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.
What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merry withal?
Keep your hundred pounds to yourself; he shall need none so long as I live.
Thou liest: his father is come from Padua, and here looking out at the window.
Art thou his father?
Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.
I have seen them in the church together. God send 'em good shipping! But who is here? Mine old master, Vicentio! Now we are undone and brought to nothing.
[Seeing BIONDELLO]  Come hither, crack-hemp.
I hope I may choose, sir.
Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?
Forgot you! No, sir. I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.
What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see thy master's father, Vincentio?
What, my old worshipful old master? Yes, marry, sir; see where he looks out of the window.
Is't so, indeed?               [He beats BIONDELLO]
Help, help, help! Here's a madman will murder me.
Help, son! help, Signior Baptista!     Exit from above
Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?
How now! what's the matter?
What, is the man lunatic?
Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir, what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.
Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.
You mistake, sir; you mistake, sir. Pray, what do you think is his name?
His name! As if I knew not his name! I have brought him up ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.
Away, away, mad ass! His name is Lucentio; and he is mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vicentio.
Lucentio! O, he hath murd'red his master! Lay hold on him, I charge you, in the Duke's name. O, my son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son, Lucentio?
Carry me to the gaol!
Stay, Officer; he shall not go to prison.
Talk not, Signior Gremio; I say he shall go to prison.
Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catch'd in this business; I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.
Swear if thou dar'st.
Nay, I dare not swear it.
Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.
Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.
Away with the dotard; to the gaol with him!
[Kneeling]  Pardon, sweet father.
Lives my sweet son?
Pardon, dear father.
Here's packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!
Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?
Cambio is chang'd into Lucentio.
I'll slit the villain's nose that would have sent me to the gaol.
[To LUCENTIO]  But do you hear, sir? Have you married my daughter without asking my good will?
Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to; but I will in to be revenged for this villainy.               Exit
And I to sound the depth of this knavery.       Exit
Husband, let's follow to see the end of this ado.
First kiss me, Kate, and we will.
What, in the midst of the street?
What, art thou asham'd of me?
No, sir; God forbid; but asham'd to kiss.
Why, then, let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.
Nay, I will give thee a kiss; now pray thee, love, stay.
Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!
Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.
Padua affords nothing but what is kind.
For both our sakes I would that word were true.
Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
Then never trust me if I be afeard.
He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.
Roundly replied.
Mistress, how mean you that?
Thus I conceive by him.
Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?
My widow says thus she conceives her tale.
Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.
A very mean meaning.
Right, I mean you.
And I am mean, indeed, respecting you.
To her, Kate!
To her, widow!
A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.
That's my office.
How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?
Believe me, sir, they butt together well.
Ay, mistress bride, hath that awakened you?
Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.
A good swift simile, but something currish.
O, O, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.
I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.
Confess, confess; hath he not hit you here?
Content. What's the wager?
Twenty crowns.
A hundred then.
Content.
A match! 'tis done.
Who shall begin?
I go.                                          Exit
Son, I'll be your half Bianca comes.
I hope better.
I know her answer.
What?
She will not.
Now, by my holidame, here comes Katherina!
What is your sir, that you send for me?
Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?
They sit conferring by the parlour fire.
Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.
And so it is. I wonder what it bodes.
Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?
The more fool you for laying on my duty.
Come, come, you're mocking; we will have no telling.
Come on, I say; and first begin with her.
She shall not.
I say she shall. And first begin with her.
Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.
Well, go thy ways, old lad, for thou shalt ha't.
'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.
But a harsh hearing when women are froward.
Now go thy ways; thou hast tam'd a curst shrow.
Boatswain!
Here, master; what cheer?
I pray now, keep below.
Where is the master, boson?
Do you not hear him? You mar our labour; keep your cabins; you do assist the storm.
Nay, good, be patient.
When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers for the name of king? To cabin! silence! Trouble us not.
Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.

None that I more love than myself. You are counsellor; if you can command these elements to silence, and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more. Use your authority; if you cannot, give thanks you have liv'd so long, and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap.-Cheerly, good hearts!-Out of our way, I say.
A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!
Work you, then.
Hang, cur; hang, you whoreson, insolent noisemaker; we are less afraid to be drown'd than thou art.
I'll warrant him for drowning, though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell, and as leaky as an unstanched wench.
What, must our mouths be cold?
I am out of patience.
Let's all sink wi' th' King.
O, woe the day!
Certainly, sir, I can.
But that I do not.
Sir, are not you my father?
Sir, most heedfully.
O, good sir, I do!
Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.
O the heavens!
How came we ashore?
Close by, my master.
But are they, Ariel, safe?
Past the mid season.
My liberty.
Before the time be out? No more!
No.
I do not, sir.
No, sir.
Sir, in Argier.
Ay, sir.
Yes, Caliban her son.

To th' syllable.

He receives comfort like cold porridge.

Sir-
One-Tell.

Therefore, my lord-
Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!

Well, I have done; but yet-
He will be talking.

Though this island seem to be desert-
Ha, ha, ha!
So, you're paid.
Uninhabitable, and almost inaccessible-
Yet-
Yet-
He could not miss't.
It must needs be of subtle, tender, and delicate temperance.
Temperance was a delicate wench.

The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
As if it had lungs, and rotten ones.

Here is everything advantageous to life.
True; save means to live.
Of that there's none, or little.
How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green!
The ground indeed is tawny.
With an eye of green in't.
He misses not much.
No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.
But the rarity of it is, which is indeed almost beyond credit-
As many vouch'd rarities are.
That our garments, being, as they were, drench'd in the sea, hold, notwithstanding, their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dy'd, than stain'd with salt water.
If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?
Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.
'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.
Tunis was never grac'd before with such a paragon to their queen.
Not since widow Dido's time.
Widow! a pox o' that! How came that 'widow' in? Widow Dido!
'Widow Dido' said you? You make me study of that. She was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.
Carthage?
I assure you, Carthage.
His word is more than the miraculous harp.
He hath rais'd the wall, and houses too.

I think he will carry this island home in his pocket, and give it his son for an apple.
And, sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.
Ay.
Why, in good time.
Sir, we were talking that our garments seem now as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now Queen.
And the rarest that e'er came there.
Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.
O, widow Dido! Ay, widow Dido.
Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it? I mean, in a sort.
That 'sort' was well fish'd for.
When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?
No, no, he's gone.
Prithee, peace.
So is the dear'st o' th' loss.
Very well.
And most chirurgeonly.
Foul weather?
Very foul.
Had I plantation of this isle, my lord-
He'd sow 't with nettle-seed.
Or docks, or mallows.
And were the king on't, what would I do?
Scape being drunk for want of wine.
Yet he would be king on't.
The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.
No marrying 'mong his subjects?
None, man; all idle; whores and knaves.
Save his Majesty!
Long live Gonzalo!
And-do you mark me, sir?
Prithee, no more; thou dost talk nothing to me.
I do well believe your Highness; and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.
'Twas you we laugh'd at.
Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you; so you may continue, and laugh at nothing still.
What a blow was there given!
An it had not fall'n flat-long.
We would so, and then go a-bat-fowling.
Nay, good my lord, be not angry.
No, I warrant you; I will not adventure my discretion so weakly. Will you laugh me asleep, for I am very heavy?
What a strange drowsiness possesses them!
It is the quality o' th' climate.
What, art thou waking?
Do you not hear me speak?
Well, I am standing water.
I'll teach you how to flow.
He's gone.
Claribel.
Methinks I do.
But, for your conscience-
Then let us both be sudden.
What's the matter?
I heard nothing.
Heard you this, Gonzalo?
Lead away.
Do not torment me. O!

What's the matter? Have we devils here? Do you put tricks upon 's with savages and men of Ind? Ha! I have not scap'd drowning to be afeard now of your four legs; for it hath been said: As proper a man as ever went on four legs cannot make him give ground; and it shall be said so again, while Stephano breathes at nostrils.
The spirit torments me. O!

This is some monster of the isle with four legs, who hath got, as I take it, an ague. Where the devil should he learn our language? I will give him some relief, if it be but for that. If I can recover him, and keep him tame, and get to Naples with him, he's a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat's leather.
Do not torment me, prithee; I'll bring my wood home faster.

Come on your ways; open your mouth; here is that which will give language to you, cat. Open your mouth; this will shake your shaking, I can tell you, and that soundly; you cannot tell who's your friend. Open your chaps again.
I should know that voice; it should be-but he is drown'd; and these are devils. O, defend me!
Stephano!
Stephano! If thou beest Stephano, touch me, and speak to me; for I am Trinculo-be not afeard-thy good friend Trinculo.
Prithee, do not turn me about; my stomach is not constant.
I'll swear upon that bottle to be thy true subject, for the liquor is not earthly.
Here; swear then how thou escap'dst.
Swum ashore, man, like a duck; I can swim like a duck, I'll be sworn.
[Passing the bottle]  Here, kiss the book. Though thou canst swim like a duck, thou art made like a goose.
O Stephano, hast any more of this?
Hast thou not dropp'd from heaven?
Out o' th' moon, I do assure thee; I was the Man i' th' Moon, when time was.
I have seen thee in her, and I do adore thee. My mistress show'd me thee, and thy dog and thy bush.
I'll show thee every fertile inch o' th' island; and will kiss thy foot. I prithee be my god.
By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster! When's god's asleep he'll rob his bottle.
I'll kiss thy foot; I'll swear myself thy subject.
Come on, then; down, and swear.
I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy- headed monster. A most scurvy monster! I could find in my heart to beat him-
Come, kiss.
But that the poor monster's in drink. An abominable monster!
A most ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard!
[Sings drunkenly]  Farewell, master; farewell, farewell!
A howling monster; a drunken monster!
You look wearily.
Do you love me?
Wherefore weep you?
My husband, then?
Servant-monster! The folly of this island! They say there's but five upon this isle: we are three of them; if th' other two be brain'd like us, the state totters.
Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee; thy eyes are almost set in thy head.
Where should they be set else? He were a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
Your lieutenant, if you list; he's no standard.
We'll not run, Monsieur Monster.
Nor go neither; but you'll lie like dogs, and yet say nothing neither.
Moon-calf, speak once in thy life, if thou beest a good moon-calf.

Thou liest, most ignorant monster: I am in case to justle a constable. Why, thou debosh'd fish, thou, was there ever man a coward that hath drunk so much sack as I to-day? Wilt thou tell a monstrous lie, being but half fish and half a monster?
Lo, how he mocks me! Wilt thou let him, my lord?
'Lord' quoth he! That a monster should be such a natural!
Lo, lo again! Bite him to death, I prithee.
Trinculo, keep a good tongue in your head; if you prove a mutineer-the next tree! The poor monster's my subject, and he shall not suffer indignity.
I thank my noble lord. Wilt thou be pleas'd to hearken once again to the suit I made to thee?
As I told thee before, I am subject to a tyrant, sorcerer, that by his cunning hath cheated me of the island.
Thou liest.
Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in's tale, by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.
Why, I said nothing.
Mum, then, and no more. Proceed.
That's most certain.
Thou shalt be lord of it, and I'll serve thee.
How now shall this be compass'd? Canst thou bring me to the party?
Thou liest; thou canst not.
Trinculo, run into no further danger; interrupt the monster one word further and, by this hand, I'll turn my mercy out o' doors, and make a stock-fish of thee.
Why, what did I? I did nothing. I'll go farther off.
Didst thou not say he lied?
Thou liest.
Do I so? Take thou that.  [Beats him]  As you like this, give me the lie another time.
I did not give the lie. Out o' your wits and hearing too? A pox o' your bottle! This can sack and drinking do. A murrain on your monster, and the devil take your fingers!
Ha, ha, ha!
Now, forward with your tale.-Prithee stand further off.
Beat him enough; after a little time, I'll beat him too.
Stand farther. Come, proceed.
Is it so brave a lass?
Excellent.
Give me thy hand; I am sorry I beat thee; but while thou liv'st, keep a good tongue in thy head.
Ay, on mine honour.
This will I tell my master.
What is this same?
This is the tune of our catch, play'd by the picture of Nobody.
If thou beest a man, show thyself in thy likeness; if thou beest a devil, take't as thou list.
O, forgive me my sins!
He that dies pays all debts. I defy thee. Mercy upon us!
Art thou afeard?
No, monster, not I.
This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall have my music for nothing.
When Prospero is destroy'd.
That shall be by and by; I remember the story.
The sound is going away; let's follow it, and after do our work.
Lead, monster; we'll follow. I would I could see this taborer; he lays it on.
What harmony is this? My good friends, hark!
Marvellous sweet music!
Give us kind keepers, heavens! What were these?
[Aside]  Praise in departing.
They vanish'd strangely.
Not I.
I'll be thy second.      Exeunt SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO
What would my potent master? Here I am.
Presently?
Ay, with a twink.
Well! I conceive.                                  Exit
We wish your peace.                 Exeunt
Thy thoughts I cleave to. What's thy pleasure?
Say again, where didst thou leave these varlets?
I go, I go.                                        Exit
Monster, your fairy, which you say is a harmless fairy, has done little better than play'd the Jack with us.
Monster, I do smell all horse-piss at which my nose is in great indignation.
So is mine. Do you hear, monster? If I should take a displeasure against you, look you-
Thou wert but a lost monster.
Ay, but to lose our bottles in the pool!
There is not only disgrace and dishonour in that, monster, but an infinite loss.
That's more to me than my wetting; yet this is your harmless fairy, monster.
I will fetch off my bottle, though I be o'er ears for my labour.
Give me thy hand. I do begin to have bloody thoughts.
Let it alone, thou fool; it is but trash.
O, ho, monster; we know what belongs to a frippery. O King Stephano!
Put off that gown, Trinculo; by this hand, I'll have that gown.
Thy Grace shall have it.
Be you quiet, monster. Mistress line, is not this my jerkin? Now is the jerkin under the line; now, jerkin, you are like to lose your hair, and prove a bald jerkin.
Do, do. We steal by line and level, an't like your Grace.
I thank thee for that jest; here's a garment for't. Wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country. 'Steal by line and level' is an excellent pass of pate; there's another garmet for't.
Monster, come, put some lime upon your fingers, and away with the rest.
Monster, lay-to your fingers; help to bear this away where my hogshead of wine is, or I'll turn you out of my kingdom. Go to, carry this.
And this.
Hey, Mountain, hey!
Silver! there it goes, Silver!
Hark, they roar.
Dost thou think so, spirit?
Mine would, sir, were I human.

I am woe for't, sir.

I say, Amen, Gonzalo!

[Aside to PROSPERO]  Was't well done?

You'd be king o' the isle, sirrah?

Go to; away!
Hence, and bestow your luggage where you found it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: A noble spirit!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, we always have confess'd it.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ho, ho, confess'd it! Hang'd it, have you not?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I take no heed of thee. Th'art an Athenian, therefore welcome. I myself would have no power; prithee let my meat make thee silent.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, in heart! and let the health go round.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Captain Alcibiades, your heart's in the field now.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than dinner of friends.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: So they were bleeding new, my lord, there's no meat like 'em; I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Would all those flatterers were thine enemies then, that then thou mightst kill 'em, and bid me to 'em.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that you would once use our hearts, whereby we might express some part of our zeals, we should think ourselves for ever perfect.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Thou weep'st to make them drink, Timon.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I promise you, my lord, you mov'd me much.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Much!                                [Sound tucket]

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Please you, my lord, there are certain ladies most desirous of admittance.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Ladies! What are their wills?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, which bears that office to signify their pleasures.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, you take us even at the best.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Faith, for the worst is filthy, and would not hold taking, I doubt me.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Flavius!

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: The little casket bring me hither.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Where be our men?

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: Here, my lord, in readiness.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: I am so far already in your gifts-

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
In delivering my son from me, I bury a s: My lord, there are certain nobles of the Senate newly alighted and come to visit you.

ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL: THE LIFE OF TIMON OF ATHENS
